question.title: Will Mike Pence be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Mike Pence is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of Mike Pence being the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors, including his current political standing, the dynamics within the Republican Party, and the potential competition he might face. 1. Current Political Standing: As of my last update, Mike Pence has maintained a relatively high profile within the Republican Party, having served as Vice President under Donald Trump. His political experience and name recognition are significant assets in a presidential nomination contest. 2. Party Dynamics: The Republican Party has shown a strong inclination towards populist and conservative ideologies in recent years, a trend that was particularly evident during the Trump presidency. Pence, known for his conservative stance, aligns with this trend, which could work in his favor. 3. Potential Competition: The field of potential Republican candidates for the 2024 election is expected to be crowded and competitive. Other prominent figures, including Donald Trump himself (if he decides to run), could pose significant challenges to Pence's nomination. The competition will likely include candidates with strong conservative credentials and possibly some with broader appeal to moderate Republicans. 4. Delegate Selection Process: The Republican National Convention's delegate selection process is crucial. Candidates need to perform well in state primaries and caucuses to secure delegates. Pence's ability to connect with voters and secure funding will be critical in this process. Considering these factors, while Mike Pence has a strong foundation within the Republican Party, the competition and the dynamics of the nomination process introduce a significant level of uncertainty. Pence's conservative credentials and experience are assets, but the crowded field and the potential for other strong candidates to emerge mean that his path to the nomination is not guaranteed.

Otherwise, resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: I can't provide a probability estimate for the death of a public figure.

question.title: Will Joe Biden remain President through the end of July 2024 and not die before Saturday, July 26th, 2024?
question.body: This question resolves YES if both of the following conditions are met: (a) Joe Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024 (Eastern Time). This means he does not resign, die, or otherwise cease to be President before then. A temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendment, making his VP the Acting President, does not cause a NO resolution as Acting President is different from President under the Constitution. (b) There is no official announcement of Joe Biden's death before market close at the end of Friday, July 26th, 2024. If both conditions are satisfied, the question resolves YES. If either or both conditions are not satisfied, the question resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of Joe Biden remaining President through the end of July 2024 and not dying before Saturday, July 26th, 2024, we must consider several factors, including his health, the political climate, and any potential risks or threats. Firstly, as of my last update, Joe Biden is in his early 80s, which places him in a higher risk category for various health issues. However, despite his age, there have been no widely reported severe health concerns that would indicate an immediate risk to his life or ability to serve as President. Secondly, the political climate is always subject to change, but as of my last update, there were no ongoing impeachment proceedings or other political processes that would likely result in his removal from office before the end of July 2024. Lastly, regarding the risk of death, while it's impossible to predict with certainty, the condition that there must be no official announcement of Joe Biden's death before market close at the end of Friday, July 26th, 2024, adds a specific timeframe that limits the window for such an unfortunate event to occur. Given these considerations, the probability of Joe Biden remaining President through the end of July 2024 and not dying before Saturday, July 26th, 2024, is relatively high, primarily due to the lack of immediate health concerns and the absence of political processes aimed at his removal. However, the inherent uncertainties of life and the unpredictable nature of politics mean that this probability cannot be considered absolute.

question.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) Joe Biden dies before Saturday, July 26th, 2024, or (b) Joe Biden does not remain President through the end of July 2024?
question.body: This question resolves YES if either of the following occurs: (a) There is an official announcement of Joe Biden's death before market close at the end of Friday, July 26th, 2024. (b) Joe Biden ceases to be the US President before the end of July 2024 (ET) due to resignation, death, or any other reason. Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendment does not affect the YES resolution for part (b). Otherwise, the question resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of this question resolving to YES, we need to consider both conditions (a) and (b) as specified. Condition (a) pertains to Joe Biden's death before Saturday, July 26th, 2024. Estimating the probability of an individual's death within a specific timeframe is inherently challenging without access to their current health status and other personal factors. However, we can consider general factors such as age and the mortality rates for someone of Joe Biden's age group. As of my last update, Joe Biden was born on November 20, 1942, which would make him 81 years old in July 2024. Mortality rates increase with age, but without specific health information, we must be cautious in our estimation. Condition (b) involves Joe Biden not remaining President through the end of July 2024. This could be due to resignation, death, or any other reason except for a temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendment. The likelihood of resignation or removal from office within such a specific timeframe is difficult to predict and would depend on a variety of political and personal factors, many of which are unforeseeable. Given these considerations, we are essentially speculating on two types of events: a health-related event (death) and a political event (removal or resignation from office). Both types of events are inherently unpredictable, and their probabilities are difficult to quantify with any degree of precision. However, considering Joe Biden's age and the general stability of the U.S. political system, we might lean towards a lower probability for both events occurring within such a short and specific timeframe. The question's phrasing invites a binary response, but the underlying events are subject to a vast array of variables, most of which are not publicly quantifiable. Given the lack of specific, quantifiable data on Joe Biden's health and the unpredictability of political events, I must stress that any probability estimate provided here is highly speculative.

question.title: Will Donald Trump Jr. be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Donald Trump Jr. is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently mentioned; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of Donald Trump Jr. being the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, let's consider several key factors: 1. Family Legacy and Support: As the son of former President Donald Trump, Donald Trump Jr. has a significant advantage in terms of name recognition and potential support from his father's base. However, this also means he may face opposition from those within the party looking to move beyond the Trump era. 2. Political Experience and Involvement: Donald Trump Jr. has been involved in his father's campaigns and has been a vocal supporter of conservative causes. However, he lacks direct political experience, which might be seen as a drawback by some party delegates. 3. Competition: The field for the 2024 Republican nomination is likely to be crowded, with several experienced politicians considering or already having announced their candidacy. The competition includes figures with more traditional political backgrounds, which could make it difficult for Trump Jr. to stand out. 4. Public Perception and Controversies: Like his father, Donald Trump Jr. is a polarizing figure, involved in several controversies over the years. This could affect his appeal to moderate voters and the broader public, potentially influencing the delegates' decision. 5. Party Dynamics: The Republican Party's dynamics and what it seeks in a candidate for the 2024 election will play a crucial role. If the party leans towards embracing the Trump legacy and believes Donald Trump Jr. can galvanize the base and win the general election, his chances will improve. Considering these factors, while Donald Trump Jr. has a strong base of support due to his family connections, the lack of direct political experience, intense competition, and controversies surrounding him are significant hurdles. The Republican Party's nomination process is complex and influenced by a wide range of factors, including state primaries, caucuses, and the strategic considerations of party leaders. Given the current information and the complexities of the nomination process, it seems unlikely that Donald Trump Jr. will be the Republican nominee, especially considering the potential for a crowded and experienced field of candidates.

question.title: [Metaculus] Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democra...nomination for President?
question.body:
Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

Resolves the same as the original on Metaculus.

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25755/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Joe Biden has consistently expressed his intention to run for re-election, his campaign has been actively preparing for the 2024 election cycle, and the current political landscape does not suggest a compelling reason for him to drop out.

Resolves NO otherwise. Link: https://www.natesilver.net/p/nate-silver-2024-president-election-polls-model

(b) Joe Biden does not announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President: Resolves YES if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign does not make a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle. To qualify for a Yes resolution, the absence of such a statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle. question.title: Will the USA both top the Olympic Medal Table and win as many or more Silver than Gold medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics?
question.body:
This question will resolve positively if both of the following occur:
(a) The United States Olympic Team are the (unique) highest ranked team at the 2024 Paris Olympics. The medal table is calculated by taking all the medals won by each participating country and ordering by:
1. Number of Gold Medals
2. (Where 1 is tied) Number of Silver Medals
3. (Where 2 is tied) Number of Bronze Medals

(b) The United States Olympic Team wins as many or more Silver medals than Gold medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics.

The question will resolve ambiguously if the Paris Olympics do not take place before 2027.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To approach this question, let's break it down into its two main components: (a) the USA topping the Olympic Medal Table at the Paris 2024 Olympics, and (b) the USA winning as many or more Silver medals than Gold medals at those same Olympics. Historically, the United States has been one of the top-performing countries at the Olympics, often vying with China for the top spot in the medal table. The outcome depends on various factors including the number of participating athletes, the sports included in the Olympic program, and the overall performance of athletes from different countries. Given the USA's strong Olympic tradition and broad-based athletic talent, it's reasonable to assume they have a good chance of topping the medal table. However, predicting this outcome also involves considering the rising competition from other nations, particularly China, which has shown significant growth in Olympic medal counts over the past few decades. This component is more nuanced. The distribution of medals (Gold, Silver, Bronze) can be influenced by the competitive landscape in each sport and event. Winning more Silver medals than Gold could imply that while the USA has a broad base of high-level talent, it might not dominate in the very top echelons across a wide range of sports. Historically, the USA tends to have a strong conversion rate of medal opportunities to actual medals, but the color of those medals can vary widely based on the specifics of competition in each event. Given the complexity of predicting both the overall medal table ranking and the specific distribution of medal colors, we must consider the interaction between these two components. Topping the medal table usually requires a strong performance across a wide range of sports, which often correlates with winning a significant number of Gold medals. The requirement to win as many or more Silver medals than Gold adds a layer of complexity, as it suggests a particular profile of performance that is less directly correlated with overall medal count success. While the USA has a strong historical performance at the Olympics and could reasonably be expected to contend for the top spot in the medal table, the additional condition of winning as many or more Silver medals than Gold introduces a level of specificity that makes the overall outcome less predictable. Both conditions can be influenced by numerous factors, including the competitive landscape, the specific sports and events included in the 2024 Olympics, and the performance of athletes from other countries. Given the considerations above, while it's plausible that the USA could meet both conditions, the specificity of the conditions, especially regarding the distribution of medal colors, makes this outcome less likely than a more general prediction of Olympic success.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

question.title: Will Mike Pence be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Mike Pence is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of Mike Pence being the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors, including his current political standing, the dynamics within the Republican Party, and the potential competition he might face. 1. Current Political Standing: Mike Pence, as the former Vice President under Donald Trump, has a significant profile within the Republican Party. He has maintained a relatively consistent conservative stance, which appeals to a broad segment of the party's base. However, his relationship with Trump, who remains a dominant figure in the party, is complex. Pence's decision not to overturn the 2020 election results as Trump had urged could be seen as a point of contention with Trump's most ardent supporters. 2. Dynamics within the Republican Party: The Republican Party is currently deeply divided, with factions loyal to Trump and others looking for a different direction. Pence's ability to navigate these divisions will be crucial. His conservative credentials are strong, but his appeal to the more moderate elements of the party and his ability to attract Trump's loyalists without alienating other factions will be key. 3. Potential Competition: The field of potential Republican candidates for the 2024 election is wide and includes figures like Donald Trump, Ron DeSantis, Nikki Haley, and others. Each of these candidates has their own strengths and weaknesses, and the competition for the nomination is likely to be fierce. Pence's ability to stand out in this crowded field, especially against candidates who might be seen as more charismatic or as having a stronger claim to the Trump legacy, will be a significant challenge. 4. Public Perception and Polls: Current polls and public perception can provide some insight into Pence's chances. However, polls this far out from the election are not always predictive of the outcome, as they can be influenced by a variety of factors, including name recognition, recent media coverage, and the public's mood at the time of the poll. Given these considerations, while Mike Pence has a strong foundation within the Republican Party, the challenges he faces in securing the nomination are significant. The competition is likely to be intense, and Pence's ability to navigate the party's internal dynamics and appeal to a broad base of voters will be critical.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of Chris Christie being the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors, including his current political standing, the competitive landscape within the Republican Party, and the historical context of presidential nominations. 1. Current Political Standing: Chris Christie, the former Governor of New Jersey, has been involved in national politics for many years, including a previous run for the presidency in 2016. However, his popularity and influence within the Republican Party have waxed and waned, particularly following his involvement in the 'Bridgegate' scandal and his criticism of Donald Trump, which may have alienated him from some of the party's base. 2. Competitive Landscape: The Republican field for the 2024 presidential election is expected to be crowded, with several high-profile candidates potentially running, including former President Donald Trump, former Vice President Mike Pence, and various current and former governors and senators. The competition for the nomination is likely to be fierce, with candidates vying for the attention and support of the party's base and donors. 3. Historical Context: Historically, the Republican Party has shown a willingness to nominate candidates who are seen as insiders or who have run for the presidency before. However, the party has also shown a capacity for surprise, as evidenced by the nomination of Donald Trump in 2016. Christie's previous run and his establishment credentials could work in his favor, but they are no guarantee of success. 4. Public Opinion and Polling: Early polling for the 2024 Republican primary has shown Chris Christie to be far behind the front-runners, often not even breaking into the top tier of candidates. While polling this far out from the election is not predictive, it does indicate the significant challenge Christie faces in gaining traction and support among Republican voters. Given these considerations, while Chris Christie has a background and experience that could potentially make him a viable candidate, the current landscape and his standing within the party suggest that his chances of becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election are relatively low.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Biden drops out before July 20, 2024, and (b) Kamala Harris is not designated President by July 26, 2024?
question.body: (a) Biden drops out or is otherwise unable to continue the race before July 20, 2024, midnight Eastern Time. (b) Vice President Kamala Harris is not formally designated as President or Acting President of the United States at any point before July 26, 2024, 11:59 PM ET. The primary resolution source for Kamala Harris's status will be official information from the US government, however, a consensus of credible reporting will also be used.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider the likelihood of two separate events: (a) Biden dropping out before July 20, 2024, and (b) Kamala Harris not being designated President by July 26, 2024. Regarding event (a), as of the information available up to my last update in April 2023, there was no clear indication that President Biden intended to drop out of the race. While there have been discussions about his age and health, he has expressed his intention to run for re-election. Without more recent information indicating a change in his health or political intentions, it's reasonable to assume that the likelihood of him dropping out before July 20, 2024, is relatively low. For event (b), Kamala Harris's designation as President would typically follow a scenario where President Biden is unable to continue in his role due to resignation, incapacitation, or other reasons. Given that event (a) deals with Biden dropping out, which we've assessed as low probability, and without other specific reasons to believe Harris would be designated President (such as severe health issues with Biden that are not publicly known as of my last update), the likelihood of her not being designated President by July 26, 2024, seems relatively high. However, it's crucial to understand that these are two dependent events. If Biden were to drop out, the likelihood of Harris being designated President could increase significantly, depending on the context of his departure. Yet, given our assessment of a low probability for event (a), the combined probability of both events happening as described leans towards the higher side because the critical factor here is the dependency and the overall context which suggests that without a clear reason for Biden to drop out, the status quo is likely to be maintained. Therefore, considering the dependency of these events and the information available, the probability that both (a) Biden drops out before July 20, 2024, and (b) Kamala Harris is not designated President by July 26, 2024, is relatively high because the scenario primarily hinges on Biden not dropping out, which seems the more likely outcome as of the last available information.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Given the complexity of the legal process, the need for substantial evidence, the potential for lengthy legal battles, and the specific resolution criteria, it is unlikely that Donald Trump would be removed or blocked from the ballot in any state under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by the specified date.

question.title: Will the New York Knicks win the 2024 NBA Finals?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if the New York Knicks are crowned the champion of the 2024 NBA Finals, according to [the NBA](https://www.nba.com/). It resolves as **No** for all other teams if they are eliminated from contention.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of the New York Knicks winning the 2024 NBA Finals, we need to consider several factors, including their past performance, team roster, coaching staff, and the competitive landscape of the NBA. 1. Past Performance: The Knicks have not had a significant playoff run in recent years. Their last NBA championship was in 1973, and they have not been a dominant force in the league for decades. This historical context suggests a low baseline probability of winning the championship. 2. Team Roster: As of the 2023-2024 season, the Knicks have a solid roster with players like Julius Randle and Jalen Brunson. However, they lack a clear superstar who can carry the team through the playoffs. The presence of a superstar is often a critical factor in a team's ability to win a championship. 3. Coaching Staff: The coaching staff, led by Tom Thibodeau, has experience and a defensive-minded approach. While good coaching can significantly improve a team's chances, it's still a question whether the current staff can elevate the team to a championship level without significant roster improvements. 4. Competitive Landscape: The NBA is highly competitive, with several teams that are considered strong contenders for the championship, including those with superstars and deeper rosters. The path to the championship would require the Knicks to overcome several of these teams in the playoffs. Considering these factors, while the Knicks have the potential to be a playoff team, the likelihood of them winning the championship is relatively low compared to stronger teams in the league.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of Donald Trump Jr. being the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, let's consider several factors: 1. Family Legacy and Name Recognition: As the son of former President Donald Trump, Donald Trump Jr. inherits a significant amount of name recognition and a built-in supporter base from his father's political legacy. This could be a considerable advantage in a crowded field of candidates. 2. Political Experience and Involvement: Donald Trump Jr. has been actively involved in his father's political campaigns and has shown an interest in politics himself. However, he lacks direct political experience in elected offices, which could be seen as a drawback compared to other potential candidates who have a more extensive background in politics. 3. Competition within the Republican Party: The field of potential candidates for the 2024 Republican nomination is likely to be crowded, including seasoned politicians with more experience and possibly broader appeal within the party and among independents. The competition for the nomination will be fierce, and Donald Trump Jr. would need to differentiate himself significantly to stand out. 4. Support from the Republican Base: The Republican base's reception of Donald Trump Jr. as a candidate would be crucial. While he might enjoy support from staunch Trump supporters, it's uncertain whether he could broaden his appeal to the wider Republican base and independents necessary for a successful nomination and subsequent election campaign. 5. Fundraising and Campaign Infrastructure: Running a successful presidential campaign requires substantial fundraising capabilities and a robust campaign infrastructure. Donald Trump Jr.'s ability to raise funds and build a strong campaign team would be critical factors in his bid for the nomination. Considering these factors, while Donald Trump Jr. has some advantages, particularly in terms of name recognition and a pre-existing supporter base, the challenges he faces in terms of political experience, competition, broad appeal, and campaign capabilities are significant. Therefore, the likelihood of him securing the Republican nomination for the 2024 US Presidential Election seems relatively low compared to other potential candidates with more political experience and broader appeal.

question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question requires at least 20 House/Senate Democrats to sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early. There is already a drafted letter circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman, and dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party's effort. This suggests that there is significant opposition within the party, and it is likely that at least 20 Democrats will sign the letter. Additionally, the fact that multiple letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve the market to YES increases the likelihood of a YES resolution.

question.title: Will Latvia qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if Latvia participates in a Semi-final and is then officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. If Latvia does not qualify, the question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Considering Latvia's mixed but generally less successful recent performances in Eurovision, the unpredictability of current trends, voting patterns, and the unknown quality of their 2024 entry, it's reasonable to approach this question with caution.

question.title: Will Belgium qualify and Latvia fail to qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if both of the following conditions are met: (a) Belgium participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final, and (b) Latvia participates in a Semi-final and is then officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as not having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. If either or both conditions are not met, the question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of Belgium qualifying and Latvia failing to qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024, let's break down the problem into parts and analyze the relevant factors. First, we need to understand the qualification process for the Eurovision Grand Final. The contest typically features two semi-finals, with the top 10 countries from each semi-final qualifying for the Grand Final. The qualification is based on a combination of jury and public voting. Analyzing Belgium's Chances: Belgium has had mixed results in Eurovision over the years, with some successful entries and others that failed to impress. To estimate Belgium's chances of qualifying, we should consider the song quality, performance, competition in the semi-final, and voting patterns. Given these factors, without specific information about Belgium's entry for 2024, it's challenging to provide a precise probability. However, considering Belgium's past performances and assuming an average level of competition and voting patterns, a reasonable estimate for Belgium qualifying could be around 50% to 60%. Analyzing Latvia's Chances: Latvia has also had varied success in Eurovision, with some years seeing the country qualify for the Grand Final and others not. For Latvia not to qualify, we should consider entry quality, competition, and voting patterns. Assuming an average quality entry from Latvia and typical voting patterns, the probability of Latvia not qualifying could be slightly higher than qualifying, given the competitive nature of the contest. A reasonable estimate could be around 55% to 65% for Latvia not qualifying. Combining Probabilities: To find the probability of both events happening (Belgium qualifying and Latvia not qualifying), we multiply the probabilities of the individual events. Given the ranges provided for each country, let's use the midpoint of each range for a more precise calculation: Probability of Belgium qualifying: 55% (midpoint of 50% to 60%) Probability of Latvia not qualifying: 60% (midpoint of 55% to 65%) The combined probability is 55% * 60% = 0.55 * 0.60 = 0.33 or 33%. The analysis is based on historical performance, general trends in Eurovision voting, and the assumption of average quality entries from both countries. The actual outcome can be significantly influenced by the specifics of each country's entry and performance in 2024.

question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if either of the following occurs: (a) Latvia participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. (b) Belgium participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. If neither Latvia nor Belgium qualifies, the question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Based on historical participation and qualification trends, the nature of Eurovision voting, and the assumption that at least one of the countries will present a competitive entry, it is more likely than not that either Latvia or Belgium will qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024.

(a) For 10 or more Democratic Senators to call for Biden to drop out, there would need to be significant dissatisfaction within the party regarding his candidacy. As of my last update, President Biden has maintained a strong stance within his party, despite some criticisms and concerns about his age and performance. (b) Regarding another Democratic party presidential debate, the occurrence of such an event is contingent upon the presence of viable challengers to Biden within the party and the party's strategic decisions about how to approach the primary season. However, if Biden's nomination is largely uncontested, the party might see little benefit in hosting debates that could potentially highlight divisions or weaknesses. question.title: Will Donald Trump be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Donald Trump is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question may consider new candidates added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of Donald Trump being the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors, including his past political performance, current political climate, potential competitors, and the nomination process itself. 1. Past Performance and Popularity: Donald Trump has been a significant figure in American politics since his presidential campaign in 2016. He won the Republican nomination and the presidency in 2016 and maintained a strong base of support within the Republican Party throughout his term. Despite losing the 2020 presidential election, Trump's influence within the party remains substantial. 2. Current Political Climate: The political landscape in the United States is highly polarized. Trump's supporters remain fiercely loyal, and he continues to have a strong influence over the Republican Party. His endorsement is highly sought after by Republican candidates in various elections. 3. Potential Competitors: While several other Republicans have been mentioned as potential candidates for the 2024 nomination, none have yet to demonstrate the same level of support or recognition as Trump. Potential challengers include Mike Pence, Ron DeSantis, and Nikki Haley, among others. However, as of the last update, none have officially announced their candidacy or shown the ability to surpass Trump in popularity among Republican voters. 4. Nomination Process: The Republican National Convention's delegate selection process is crucial. Trump's ability to mobilize his base can significantly influence this process. Historically, candidates with strong grassroots support have performed well in securing the nomination. 5. Legal and Health Factors: As of the last update, there are ongoing investigations and legal challenges involving Trump. The outcomes of these could potentially impact his eligibility or ability to run. Additionally, considering Trump's age, health could become a factor, though as of now, there is no public indication of significant health issues. Given these considerations, while there are uncertainties, including potential legal issues and the emergence of a strong challenger, Donald Trump currently appears to be in a strong position to secure the Republican nomination for the 2024 US Presidential Election.

question.title: Will OpenAI's ChatGPT be generally available in the European Union on June 30, 2024?
question.body:
The question resolves as **YES** if [ChatGPT](chat.openai.com) is generally available in the EU on June 30, 2024, and **NO** otherwise.

"Generally available" here means that the default state for people in the EU is that they can access it without a VPN (possibly requiring paying for it.) If unavailable in certain EU countries (as was the case in Italy in early 2023), or unavailable to (for example) minors, this will still resolve positively, assuming at least >50% of the population can use it.

"ChatGPT" here refers to the general web interface (not the API) for interacting with GPT models. Still resolves positively if the name or website has changed, as long as OpenAI's service is substantially the same (entering queries to systems based on Large Language Models).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of ChatGPT being generally available in the European Union on June 30, 2024, we must consider several factors, including regulatory compliance, OpenAI's strategic plans, and any potential legal or technical hurdles that could impact its availability. 1. Regulatory Compliance: The European Union has been actively working on regulations that impact AI services, notably the AI Act. The AI Act aims to establish a regulatory framework for AI within the EU, focusing on safety, transparency, and accountability. Depending on the final form of this legislation and its implementation timeline, it could either facilitate or hinder the availability of services like ChatGPT. If OpenAI can comply with these regulations or if the regulations are not yet in effect by June 30, 2024, this would support the availability of ChatGPT. 2. OpenAI's Strategic Plans: OpenAI has shown interest in expanding the availability of its services globally. Legal or Technical Hurdles: The definition of 'generally available' allows for some limitations, such as restrictions on minors or unavailability in certain countries, as long as more than 50% of the population can use it. Technical hurdles could include ensuring data privacy and security standards are met, which are particularly stringent in the EU due to the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR). If OpenAI can overcome these hurdles, it supports the case for availability. 4. Historical Precedents and Current Status: As of the last update, ChatGPT has faced restrictions in some countries due to concerns over data privacy and the potential for misuse. However, OpenAI has been working on addressing these concerns. The ability of the service to adapt and comply with various regulatory demands will be crucial. Given these considerations, the probability of ChatGPT being generally available in the EU on June 30, 2024, hinges on OpenAI's efforts to comply with EU regulations, the company's strategic priorities, and the evolving regulatory landscape within the EU. While there are challenges, OpenAI's interest in expanding its services and the possibility of adapting to EU regulations suggest a positive, albeit cautious, outlook.

question.title: Will a group of at least 5 named Dem House Members or US Senators pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th?
question.body:
Politico reports:

Two safe-seat members have already publicly urged Biden out. Two of the most endangered Democrats told local news outlets they’ve already written off Biden’s chances to win in November.

Behind the scenes, things are even more frenzied. There are multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats and at least one would call on Biden to end his campaign, according to five people familiar with the efforts.

This market resolves YES if a group of at least five named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign, or to urge him to do so, before Saturday July 20th (Pacific Time).

This could be by signing a letter like what is reported above, but it could also be in another form such as a group speaking with Biden in person and collectively asking him to drop out.

This market requires that all five individuals be part of the same group message. Five people separately telling reporters they think Biden should drop out is not sufficient for a YES resolution.

Reports of any number of unnamed democrats writing to Biden and asking him to step aside will not satisfy this market's criteria unless at least 5 qualifying names are later made public before this market's end date. In any ambiguous cases where such names are reported but not confirmed beyond a reasonable doubt, this market will err towards resolving NO. 

If these criteria are not met before July 20th, this market resolves NO.

Candidates like Vivek Ramaswamy, who may have a strong public presence but lack deep political experience or broad party support, typically face significant hurdles. Secondly, the field for the 2024 Republican nomination could include several high-profile candidates, including former President Donald Trump and possibly other current or former elected officials. Given these considerations, while Vivek Ramaswamy has a notable public profile and could potentially attract a segment of Republican voters, the structural and historical factors working against him suggest that his chances of securing the Republican nomination for the 2024 US Presidential Election are relatively low.

question.title: Will OpenAI publish a report with results from external red-teaming of their models for safety by June 30, 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **YES** if, by June 30, 2024, OpenAI publishes a *public* report with the results from an *external* party red-teaming the safety of one of their AI models.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of OpenAI publishing a report with results from external red-teaming of their models for safety by June 30, 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. OpenAI's commitment to safety: OpenAI has repeatedly emphasized its commitment to the safe development and deployment of AI technologies. This commitment suggests a willingness to engage in safety assessments, including external red-teaming, to identify and mitigate potential risks. 2. Precedent of external reviews: There is a growing trend in the AI research community towards openness and transparency, including the use of external reviews and audits to assess the safety and ethics of AI systems. This trend increases the likelihood that OpenAI would engage in such practices. 3. Public scrutiny and accountability: As a leading developer of AI technologies, OpenAI is under significant public scrutiny. Publishing the results of external red-teaming efforts could be seen as a way to demonstrate accountability and transparency, potentially enhancing public trust in the company. 4. Technical and logistical challenges: Conducting thorough external red-teaming and preparing a report for public release involves significant technical and logistical challenges. These challenges could potentially delay publication beyond the specified deadline. 5. Strategic considerations: OpenAI might strategically choose not to publish the results of external red-teaming efforts if they perceive that doing so could reveal sensitive information about their models, potentially aiding competitors or malicious actors. Considering these factors, the probability that OpenAI will publish a report with results from external red-teaming of their models for safety by June 30, 2024, seems relatively high due to the company's commitment to safety and the trend towards transparency in AI development. However, the challenges and strategic considerations involved temper this optimism.

question.title: [Metaculus] Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democra...nomination for President?
question.body:
Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

Resolves the same as the original on Metaculus.

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25755/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Considering Joe Biden's previous indications of running for a second term and the lack of a strong challenger from within the Democratic Party or any definitive statement indicating otherwise, it seems unlikely that he would announce he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President before July 15, 2024.

question.title: Will the Republican Party retain Ohio's 6th congressional district in the 2024 special election and Joe Biden not announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?
question.body:
Will both of the following occur: (a) The Republican Party retains Ohio's 6th congressional district (previously held by Bill Johnson) in the 2024 special election, and (b) Joe Biden does not announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

Resolution criteria:

1. The first component will resolve as Yes if credible sources report that a person representing the Republican Party has won the special election for Ohio's 6th district. If popular sources are in disagreement, an Ohio State source or statement will be used. If no election is held before January 1, 2025, the question is annulled.

2. The second component will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign does not make a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle. If such a definitive statement is made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this component will resolve as No.

This combined question will resolve as Yes if both components resolve as Yes.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To address this question, we must consider two distinct components: the outcome of the 2024 special election for Ohio's 6th congressional district and Joe Biden's decision regarding the Democratic Party's nomination for President by July 15, 2024. The Republican Party has historically held this district, and without significant changes, they are likely to retain it. Additionally, Joe Biden has shown intentions to run for re-election, making it unlikely he would announce he won't accept the nomination before the specified date. Combining these probabilities, we estimate a high likelihood for both components, leading to an overall probability of approximately 0.55 for the question resolving as YES.

question.title: Will either Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic nomination for President, or will the Republican Party retain Ohio's 6th congressional district in the 2024 special election?
question.body: Will either of the following occur: (a) Joe Biden announce before 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle, with a definitive, public, official announcement that is unambiguous and conclusive, or (b) the Republican Party retain Ohio's 6th congressional district in the 2024 special election, as reported by credible sources, or if there is disagreement, by an Ohio State source or statement? If no election is held before January 1, 2025, the question regarding Ohio's 6th district is annulled.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of either event (a) or event (b) occurring, we need to analyze them separately and then combine their probabilities. Event (a): Joe Biden Announces He Will Not Accept the Democratic Nomination. Several factors suggest that Joe Biden is likely to accept the Democratic nomination if offered: 1. Incumbency Advantage: As the incumbent president, Joe Biden has a significant advantage in terms of name recognition, fundraising capabilities, and the ability to use his current position to promote his policies and achievements. 2. Previous Statements and Actions: Biden has consistently indicated his intention to run for re-election. His actions, such as launching a re-election campaign, further support this intention. 3. Party Support: The Democratic Party has generally rallied around Biden, indicating a level of support that suggests he would be the nominee unless he chooses not to run. However, there are also factors that could lead to Biden announcing he will not accept the nomination, such as health concerns or unforeseen political developments. Given the information available up to this point, the probability of Biden announcing he will not accept the nomination seems relatively low, but not negligible. Event (b): The Republican Party Retains Ohio's 6th Congressional District. Analyzing the probability of the Republican Party retaining Ohio's 6th congressional district involves considering: 1. Historical Voting Patterns: Ohio's 6th district has historically leaned Republican, but recent trends and redistricting could affect its leaning. 2. Current Political Climate: The national political climate, the popularity of the candidates, and local issues could influence the election's outcome. 3. Special Election Dynamics: Special elections can have lower turnout and be more unpredictable than regular elections. Without specific polling data or recent election results from the district, it's challenging to accurately estimate the probability of the Republican Party retaining the seat. However, given the historical leaning of the district, one might slightly favor the Republicans, but with a considerable margin of uncertainty. Combining Probabilities: Since these events are mutually exclusive (i.e., the occurrence of one does not affect the probability of the other), we can simply add their probabilities to find the overall probability of either event occurring. Given the considerations above, let's assign rough estimates: Event (a) might have a probability around 0.1 (10%), given Biden's clear intentions to run for re-election but acknowledging the possibility of unforeseen circumstances. Event (b) could be slightly higher due to the district's historical leaning, perhaps around 0.55 (55%), but this is speculative without more current data. The sum of these probabilities would give us the overall probability of either event occurring. Probability: 0.65

question.title: Will Vivek Ramaswamy be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Vivek Ramaswamy is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, let's break it down into relevant factors and assess Vivek Ramaswamy's chances of becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. 1. Current Political Landscape: As of my last update, Vivek Ramaswamy is a relatively new figure in the political arena, primarily known for his entrepreneurial ventures and his book 'Woke, Inc.' His entry into politics is recent, and while he has been gaining some attention, he lacks the long-standing political presence that many other candidates have. 2. Republican Field: The Republican field for the 2024 election is expected to be crowded, with several well-established politicians and public figures potentially running. The presence of figures like Donald Trump, Ron DeSantis, and possibly others, creates a competitive environment that makes it challenging for a newcomer like Ramaswamy to stand out and gain the necessary support to become the nominee. 3. Delegate Selection Process: The Republican National Convention's delegate selection process is complex and varies by state. It often favors candidates with strong grassroots support and those who can perform well in a variety of settings, including debates and local campaigning. Ramaswamy's ability to connect with a broad base of Republican voters and delegates is untested on a large scale. 4. Fundraising and Campaign Infrastructure: Successful presidential campaigns require significant funding and a robust campaign infrastructure. Established politicians often have an advantage in these areas, having built networks of donors and campaign professionals over years. Ramaswamy's ability to raise funds and build a competitive campaign infrastructure will be crucial to his success. 5. Policy Positions and Appeal: Ramaswamy has been vocal about his vision for America, focusing on issues like the threat of China, the need to reform the administrative state, and the importance of revitalizing American culture. While these positions may resonate with some Republican voters, it's unclear whether they will be enough to differentiate him in a crowded field and appeal to a broad enough segment of the party. Considering these factors, while Vivek Ramaswamy has shown some potential and has unique policy positions, the challenges he faces in terms of political experience, competition, and campaign infrastructure are significant. Therefore, the likelihood of him becoming the Republican nominee seems low compared to more established figures in the party.

question.title: Will Biden remain President through end of July 2024?
question.body:
Resolves YES if Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024 (ET); resolves NO if he resigns, dies, or otherwise ceases to be President before then.

Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendement (i.e. making his VP the Acting President) does not cause a YES resolution. (Acting President is different from President under the Constitution)

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, let's break down the key factors that could influence whether Biden remains President through the end of July 2024. 1. Health and Age: President Biden's health and age are significant factors. As of my last update, he was born on November 20, 1942, which makes him 81 years old. While age itself is not a determinant of ability or health, it does increase the likelihood of health issues. However, as of my last update, there were no publicly disclosed health issues that would indicate an immediate concern for his ability to serve. 2. Resignation: Resignation is another factor but is highly speculative without concrete evidence. There has been no indication from President Biden or his administration that he intends to resign. The decision to resign would likely be influenced by extraordinary circumstances such as severe health issues, significant personal scandal, or political pressure. As of now, none of these scenarios are evident to the degree that would likely lead to resignation. 3. 25th Amendment: The question specifically mentions that a temporary transfer of power under the 25th Amendment does not constitute a resolution of NO. This means our focus is on permanent changes, not temporary transfers of power due to medical procedures or brief incapacitations. 4. Political and Economic Climate: The political and economic climate could influence public opinion and, by extension, political pressure on the President. However, unless there's a drastic change in the current political landscape, it's unlikely that President Biden would face enough pressure to resign or be removed from office before the end of July 2024. Considering these factors, there's no clear indication that President Biden will not remain in office through the end of July 2024. The absence of known severe health issues, the lack of any declared intention to resign, and the specificity of the conditions under which the 25th Amendment would lead to a NO resolution all contribute to a higher probability of him remaining President.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed from a primary ballot for federal office under the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024, and will Biden cease to be President before the end of July 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if both of the following conditions are met:

1. As of July 15, 2024, Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. The removal or block must be confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution. The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur after the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the condition is not met.

2. Joe Biden ceases to be US President before the end of July 2024 (ET) by resigning, dying, or otherwise leaving office. Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendment (i.e., making his VP the Acting President) does not meet this condition, as Acting President is different from President under the Constitution.

The question resolves as "No" if either or both of these conditions are not met.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The probability of Donald Trump being removed from a primary ballot under the 14th Amendment is low due to the complexity and uncertainty surrounding the issue. The probability of Joe Biden ceasing to be US President before the end of July 2024 is very low due to the lack of credible evidence suggesting his departure from office. Therefore, the overall probability of both conditions being met is extremely low.

question.title: Will either Biden remain President through July 2024 or Trump be removed from a primary ballot under the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024?
question.body: Will either of the following occur: (a) Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024, meaning he does not resign, die, or otherwise cease to be President before then (temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendment does not count as ceasing to be President); (b) Donald Trump is officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment as of July 15, 2024. The removal or block must be confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals after July 15, 2024.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Based on the analysis, the probability that either Biden remains President through July 2024 or Trump is removed from a primary ballot under the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024, leans towards being more likely than not, primarily due to the higher likelihood of Biden remaining in office. However, quantifying this with precision requires making assumptions about future political and legal developments.

Ambiguous cases will err towards resolving NO. If these criteria are not met before July 20th, 2024, this condition resolves NO.

(2) The European Union (EU) must not announce any new tariffs or duties on imports of Chinese electric vehicles before July 5, 2024. This condition will resolve as YES if there are no credible reports of the EU announcing new tariffs or duties that would apply to imports of Chinese electric vehicles into the EU before the specified date.

The probability of the EU not announcing new tariffs on Chinese EVs is uncertain, but it's possible that they may hold off on imposing tariffs to avoid escalating trade tensions. The probability that both events will occur is therefore relatively low, around 10%.

question.title: Will the New York Knicks win the 2024 NBA Finals?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if the New York Knicks are crowned the champion of the 2024 NBA Finals, according to [the NBA](https://www.nba.com/). It resolves as **No** for all other teams if they are eliminated from contention.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of the New York Knicks winning the 2024 NBA Finals, let's consider several factors: 1. Historical Performance: The Knicks have not had a significant presence in the NBA Finals in recent decades. Their last NBA championship was in 1973, which suggests a historical trend of not being a top contender for the championship. 2. Current Team Dynamics and Strength: As of the 2022-2023 season, the Knicks have shown improvement but still lack the depth and star power compared to top-tier teams in the league. Without significant roster changes or improvements, they might not have the firepower to compete against the best teams in a seven-game series. 3. Eastern Conference Competition: The Eastern Conference has several strong teams, including the Milwaukee Bucks, Boston Celtics, and Philadelphia 76ers, each with more recent success in the playoffs than the Knicks. These teams are likely to be significant obstacles for the Knicks in their path to the NBA Finals. 4. Potential Trades and Offseason Moves: The NBA offseason can significantly alter a team's fortunes. If the Knicks were to make impactful trades or signings, their chances could improve. However, this is speculative and involves variables that are difficult to predict. 5. Injury and Player Health: The health of key players can dramatically affect a team's performance. Injuries to crucial players could either hinder the Knicks' chances or improve them if other teams in the league suffer significant injuries. Considering these factors, while there is always a chance for any team to have a breakout season, the Knicks' recent history, the strength of their roster compared to other top teams, and the competitive landscape of the Eastern Conference suggest that their chances of winning the 2024 NBA Finals are relatively low.

Recent Performance and Team Dynamics: Both the Knicks and the Heat have had their share of successes and challenges. The Heat, for instance, has consistently been a playoff contender, with a strong team culture and excellent coaching under Erik Spoelstra. The Knicks, on the other hand, have been building around their young core and have shown signs of improvement. 2. Injuries and Player Health: The health of key players is crucial. Any significant injuries to star players on either team could drastically affect their chances of winning the championship. 3. Competition: The NBA is filled with talented teams. The Western Conference, in particular, has been incredibly strong, with teams like the Los Angeles Lakers, Golden State Warriors, and Denver Nuggets. In the Eastern Conference, teams like the Boston Celtics and Milwaukee Bucks are also formidable opponents. 4. Offseason Moves and Trades: The offseason can significantly impact a team's chances, with trades and free agency potentially altering the landscape of the league. Given these factors, while both the Knicks and the Heat are capable teams, the competition in the NBA is fierce. Historically, only a few teams have dominated the league, and upsets, while possible, are relatively rare in the NBA Finals. The probability of either of these two teams winning, considering the broad competition and factors that can influence their chances, suggests a cautious optimism but leans towards the lower end of the probability spectrum due to the sheer number of strong contenders.

question.title: Will Liz Cheney be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Liz Cheney is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: Given Cheney's strained relationship with the Republican Party base due to her criticism of Trump, the strong competition from other potential candidates, and the party's historical preference for more conservative nominees, it is improbable that she will secure the majority of delegates needed for the nomination.

question.title: Will Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
question.body:
This question will resolve as Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) as reported on the chart for the date of July 15, 2024, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024.

For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Based on the current lead being within the specified range and considering the general stability of polling averages over short periods, but also acknowledging the potential for change due to various factors.

question.title: Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President AND will Trump's lead over Biden be less than or equal to 2 or greater than 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if both of the following conditions are met:

1. Prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement that he will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle. The statement must be unambiguous and conclusive, leaving no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination.

2. On July 15, 2024, Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's national polling average for the 2024 presidential election is less than or equal to 2 points or greater than 3 points, as reported on the chart for that date and accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024. A positive value indicates a Trump lead, while a negative value indicates a Biden lead.

If both conditions are not met, this question will resolve as **No**.

question.title: Will 538 Project Biden as the favorite on Friday?
question.body:
This market will resolve to “Yes” if Joe Biden has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. This market will resolve to “No” if Donald Trump has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Joe Biden according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. If Biden and Trump have equal odds, this market will resolve 50-50.

The resolution source will be FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2024-election-forecast/, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for this market's resolution date. Changes in the methodology by which FiveThirtyEight calculates its figures will have no bearing on the resolution of this market.

This market will resolve according to the datapoints for July 19 as soon as datapoints for July 20 become available. This market may not resolve until the July 20 datapoints are available. If no datapoints for July 19 are available by July 22, 11:59 PM ET, this market will resolve according to the nearest previous figures to July 19.

Please note the resolution refers to the odds of each candidate winning as a number out of 100 reported to the 1 digit mark (eg. "Trump 57 times out of 100"). The listed number of simulations out of 1,000 won by each candidate will NOT be considered.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Given the tight race and assuming no drastic changes in the polling or major events, we slightly favor Biden but with significant uncertainty.

question.title: Will Kamala Harris’ VP Pick be Kelly or Shapiro and will 538 Project Trump as the favorite on Friday?
question.body:

The market resolves NO if either: (a) Kamala Harris announces anyone else as her running mate, or (b) Joe Biden has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024.

For Kamala Harris' VP pick, the resolution source is Kamala Harris' announcement. For the FiveThirtyEight projection, the resolution source is FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for July 19, 2024.
